FOX ALBANY AND HUDSON.

 Leaves Litchfeld daily Sundays excepted,l at O. clock in the morning, arrives at each place af ternoon and returns from each place in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND NEW-HAVEN.

 Leaves Litch6eld for New-Haven daily Sundays excepted) at o'clock in the morning; Monday, Wed nesday and Friday, by BethIem, Woodhury, Southbu- ry Oxford, Humphreys-Ville and arrives in N Haven at P. M.; Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, by Watertown, Waterbury, Salem-bridge, and Wood- bridge, arrives at N. Haven at 9 F. M; and returns from N. Haven in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND HARTFORD.

 Leaves Ltchfeld for Hartford, Tuesdays, Thurs days and Saturdays at o'clock in the morning thro' Harwinton, Burlington, Pennington and West-Hart- ford and arrives in Hartford at o'clock F. M. Re- turns from Hartford Mondays Wednesdays and Fri days at o'clock in the morning.

 LITCHFIELD AND NORWALK.

 Leaves Litch6eld for New-Mlford, Danbury and Norwak every Friday afternoon arrival of the Stage from Hartford, through Bradeys-Vie, New Preston, New-Miford, Brookfeld, Danbury, Reading, and Wilton, and arrives at Norwak on Saturday at 12 o'clock at noon. Returns from Norwak Sundays, arrives at Ltch6ed Monday afternoon.

 This Line intersects the Steamboat at Norwalk and arrives i'll N. York same night.

 The Steam-Boat leaves N. Haven for N. York eve- " evening at o'clock.

 The Steam Boats leave Hartford for N. York Mon days, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at II o'clock A. M.

 For information passage in the above Lines ap- ply to J. PARKS. Litchfeld, June II, 1897. tf52

 Has been determined on by large number of lib- eral gentlemen of that city, and is to be edited by the subscriber, with associate of distinguished literary attainments. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER de- voted principally to commere and manufactures but including politics, literature, and whatever else that may be Interesting to intelligent of business Ad- vertisnens for the theatre, of lottery tickets and of business be transacted the Sabbath, will be ex- cluded. It is intended that the Shipping List shall not be surpassed in the country, especially will thorough attention be paid Eastern vessels than is usual in NewYork. A price current will be inserted as soon arrangements can be made to furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same as other New-Yor papers, $lO--A Journal will be is- sued SEMl-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4 To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- to any pccuniary advantage. They have higher motive and which has long interested the feelings of fmoral and religious men in Boston, New-York and other cities Theyare ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But it is ev- dent that to accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in New York; but the enterprise is new m its character and hps to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor nor expense oRthe part of the projectors the Ed ifors will be spared And they invite the hearty operation of all those who would sustain the business of the country and it's civil and literary institutions, aEty.

 The publication will be commenced as soon as the details of preparation can be arranged. And it is re- quested that names should be returned soon without the payment of postage, to Arther Tappan Esq., New York. DAVID HALE.

4TY CT cUrS ON RELIGIOUS TRACTS.

 10 a large manufacturing town in tAe West Riding. Yorkshire. some piOus persons are in the habit of leaving tracts at the dwellings of the poor. This is done every Sunday mOrn- ing, and the same tract is deposited at each habitatiom. On ohe OccasiOn, the narrative of" WILLIAM KELLV;" the frOntispiece of which represents the subject of the story, sneaking hare headed from the presence of a storming hostess, who had seized his hat as security for tavern score. Such circum- stance actually did take place, and proved tine turning point of his life, who was after wards appropriately designated, The happy Christian" The disgrace of the incident induced sober reflection, sober reflection Is- sued in repentance, and repentance in one of the most pleasing specimens oflowiy piety that modern days can boast.

 This tract thus embellished was left among other houses at the house of one of the most proAigate drunkards in the place; and to him strange to say circumstance precisely sim liar to that which arrested Kelly in his career, had occurred the evening before. His hat be- ing detained for debt by the landlady of neighbouring ale house, he ~h had hastened homeward, bare headed, incensed and asham- ed, and had retired to rest raging like she bear robbed of her young. Sunday morning found him sullen and purturbed; he hurried down stairs half dressed, and flung himself ln- to a chair, which stood beside the breakfast table-when To, the first object that caught his attention was the frontispiece 1.-the tract which we have been describing, placed we will not say accidentally, full in his view. Glancing at it, with an eye of fierceness, he seized it, and striking the table with his fist, at the same time uttering fearful impreca- tion, exclaimed, "Those villanOus Method jsts tiff they hav'nt got me already painted up to be the laughing stock of the whole town; here am without a hat. I'll be even with them.' Thus he raved till the tempest ofhis ire had somewhat exhausted itself in oaths and menaces; ; then prompted by curi- osity, he thought he would ascertain what was said concerning him. A near inspection of the object of his wrath Immediately cor rected his preposterous error but his curios- ty having beeu excited, he peruscd the little. narrative, and the perusal was productive of the happiest effects. He resolved in the strength of God that he would reform, he re- paired to place ofpublic worship, began to search the Scriptures, and exhibited every symptom of real repentance. He is now if rightly recollect, in the employ of the gen tleman who related the InGidont, and from being disgrace to society, a curse to his neighbourhood, and scourge to his family, he has become one of the kindest of neigh bours, faithfulest of servants, best of fathers, and soberest of men.-Lond. The work is go generally known to all who acquainted with the publications of the present day, that is deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents"

 The first edition of this work, (the constant and in- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which 1t IS deservedly hed begun in 1788 and published in London, in numbers, consisted of 5000 copies the second m l8O5 of2 OOO the third in 18lO 900; the fourth in 1872 of and the edition is Stete ope, the largest work ever submitted to that process. Besides these, eight other editions, consisting, alto gether, of 2525O copies, were printed in the United States of America, from 1908 to Recorder.

NOTICE.

Rec. D.. Dasa.-" Dr. ScOtt's Commentary, has merted and obtained distinguish ed popularity. The spirit which pervades the work is excellent. is tho meek, aectionate, healing yet faithful spirit of the Gospel.

 Beside tke GbOve MANY OTHERS of the most iu- RuentiaL aOngt the Clergy hGUe recOHDeded tis 'OOr the JoiiOaUisg attracts hO'OeUer from Mr. EmerSons letter oM point out the adUGntages peculiar Co the OC- TAVO edition.

 Rep. Joseph Emerson, Author Of the EUGHgeIicM Primer" Six editions of this great work have bees published in this cOuntry.-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these editions, and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARMSFRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, the volumes not nearly so large as aae quarto editions but te paper finer and winter; the execution handsOmer; the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less inconvenience, it may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure. It has the advantage of be- ing cheaper less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 S'ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which most highly recommend for the use of families. It is peculiarly calculated supersede the of large Bible; and in two respects it will answer better purpose merely for reading the scrip tures as it is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same tine.''

FOX ALBANY AND HUDSON.

 Leaves Litchfeld daily Sundays excepted,l at O. clock in the morning, arrives at each place af ternoon and returns from each place in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND NEW-HAVEN.

 Leaves Litch6eld for New-Haven daily Sundays excepted) at o'clock in the morning; Monday, Wed nesday and Friday, by BethIem, Woodhury, Southbu- ry Oxford, Humphreys-Ville and arrives in N Haven at P. M.; Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, by Watertown, Waterbury, Salem-bridge, and Wood- bridge, arrives at N. Haven at 9 F. M; and returns from N. Haven in the same order.

 LITCHFIELD AND HARTFORD.

 Leaves Ltchfeld for Hartford, Tuesdays, Thurs days and Saturdays at o'clock in the morning thro' Harwinton, Burlington, Pennington and West-Hart- ford and arrives in Hartford at o'clock F. M. Re- turns from Hartford Mondays Wednesdays and Fri days at o'clock in the morning.

 LITCHFIELD AND NORWALK.

 Leaves Litch6eld for New-Mlford, Danbury and Norwak every Friday afternoon arrival of the Stage from Hartford, through Bradeys-Vie, New Preston, New-Miford, Brookfeld, Danbury, Reading, and Wilton, and arrives at Norwak on Saturday at 12 o'clock at noon. Returns from Norwak Sundays, arrives at Ltch6ed Monday afternoon.

 This Line intersects the Steamboat at Norwalk and arrives i'll N. York same night.

 The Steam-Boat leaves N. Haven for N. York eve- " evening at o'clock.

 The Steam Boats leave Hartford for N. York Mon days, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at II o'clock A. M.

 For information passage in the above Lines ap- ply to J. PARKS. Litchfeld, June II, 1897. tf52

FROM cLEEGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS.

 From the Rer. Dr. GriEa.-"I esteem Dr. Scott's Family Bible, emnently calculated to promote the cause of truth and pety. It scarcely possible tor me to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man."

 Rev. Asa Eaton, pastor of Christ Church, Boston. TO POSSESS For the of your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers"

 Rev. Dr. Joshaa Bates, President of Middle6u,y Couege.-"Sir am pleased with your proposals for publishing Scouts Family Bible, and sincerely wish you success in your undertaking. have doubt tha, twill be well patronzed by the religious public

 Rev Daniet Sharp, pastor of the Sd Baptist Church. BOstoa-" The more it is read by pious Christians the more extensive will be it's circulation.

 Reu. Dr. BGLdtcia, late pastor of the 2d BaptiSt CRGrh, Bosfon."I feel free to say that in my esti- mation deservedy ranks among ablest and best Commentaries. An the leading doctrines of Chris tanity as professed and maintained by many of the most eminent Reomers are in my judgment very hap piiv illustrated and enforced"

 Has been determined on by large number of lib- eral gentlemen of that city, and is to be edited by the subscriber, with associate of distinguished literary attainments. It is to be DAILY MORNING PAPER de- voted principally to commere and manufactures but including politics, literature, and whatever else that may be Interesting to intelligent of business Ad- vertisnens for the theatre, of lottery tickets and of business be transacted the Sabbath, will be ex- cluded. It is intended that the Shipping List shall not be surpassed in the country, especially will thorough attention be paid Eastern vessels than is usual in NewYork. A price current will be inserted as soon arrangements can be made to furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same as other New-Yor papers, $lO--A Journal will be is- sued SEMl-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4 To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- to any pccuniary advantage. They have higher motive and which has long interested the feelings of fmoral and religious men in Boston, New-York and other cities Theyare ready to sacrifice money, to any amount which may be required. But it is ev- dent that to accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. good subscription list has been obtained in New York; but the enterprise is new m its character and hps to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor nor expense oRthe part of the projectors the Ed ifors will be spared And they invite the hearty operation of all those who would sustain the business of the country and it's civil and literary institutions, aEty.

 The publication will be commenced as soon as the details of preparation can be arranged. And it is re- quested that names should be returned soon without the payment of postage, to Arther Tappan Esq., New York. DAVID HALE.

4TY CT cUrS ON RELIGIOUS TRACTS.

 10 a large manufacturing town in tAe West Riding. Yorkshire. some piOus persons are in the habit of leaving tracts at the dwellings of the poor. This is done every Sunday mOrn- ing, and the same tract is deposited at each habitatiom. On ohe OccasiOn, the narrative of" WILLIAM KELLV;" the frOntispiece of which represents the subject of the story, sneaking hare headed from the presence of a storming hostess, who had seized his hat as security for tavern score. Such circum- stance actually did take place, and proved tine turning point of his life, who was after wards appropriately designated, The happy Christian" The disgrace of the incident induced sober reflection, sober reflection Is- sued in repentance, and repentance in one of the most pleasing specimens oflowiy piety that modern days can boast.

 This tract thus embellished was left among other houses at the house of one of the most proAigate drunkards in the place; and to him strange to say circumstance precisely sim liar to that which arrested Kelly in his career, had occurred the evening before. His hat be- ing detained for debt by the landlady of neighbouring ale house, he ~h had hastened homeward, bare headed, incensed and asham- ed, and had retired to rest raging like she bear robbed of her young. Sunday morning found him sullen and purturbed; he hurried down stairs half dressed, and flung himself ln- to a chair, which stood beside the breakfast table-when To, the first object that caught his attention was the frontispiece 1.-the tract which we have been describing, placed we will not say accidentally, full in his view. Glancing at it, with an eye of fierceness, he seized it, and striking the table with his fist, at the same time uttering fearful impreca- tion, exclaimed, "Those villanOus Method jsts tiff they hav'nt got me already painted up to be the laughing stock of the whole town; here am without a hat. I'll be even with them.' Thus he raved till the tempest ofhis ire had somewhat exhausted itself in oaths and menaces; ; then prompted by curi- osity, he thought he would ascertain what was said concerning him. A near inspection of the object of his wrath Immediately cor rected his preposterous error but his curios- ty having beeu excited, he peruscd the little. narrative, and the perusal was productive of the happiest effects. He resolved in the strength of God that he would reform, he re- paired to place ofpublic worship, began to search the Scriptures, and exhibited every symptom of real repentance. He is now if rightly recollect, in the employ of the gen tleman who related the InGidont, and from being disgrace to society, a curse to his neighbourhood, and scourge to his family, he has become one of the kindest of neigh bours, faithfulest of servants, best of fathers, and soberest of men.-Lond.  'The work contains the Old and New Testaments with copous Marginal References; also valuable Notes explanatory of the Scriptures and, lastly, the Pract cal Observations. The work is go generally known to all who acquainted with the publications of the present day, that is deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents"

 The first edition of this work, (the constant and in- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which 1t IS deservedly hed begun in 1788 and published in London, in numbers, consisted of 5000 copies the second m l8O5 of2 OOO the third in 18lO 900; the fourth in 1872 of and the edition is Stete ope, the largest work ever submitted to that process. Besides these, eight other editions, consisting, alto gether, of 2525O copies, were printed in the United States of America, from 1908 to Recorder.

full articles.article:
DEUBEN HERMAN would inform lN the public that he has opened a Shop in Litchfeld, a few rods east of the Meeting house at the Stand lately occupied by l. Bunce Esq. where he will attend to the business, of Clock and Watch repairing, and Silver Smith, and keeps on hand an assortment of such ar ticles as are usually called for in his line, as low as can be bought elsewhere, ,ameng which are Silver Spectacles, Spoons, Jewefry, s1c. also few first rate Brass eight day Clocks. He solicits share of the public patronage.

 As DENTIST he will set teeth in the best manner for those wbO may favour him with their custom.-Cash paid for old Silver.

 Litchfeld, May 80, 1897. 6w5O

Rec. D.. Dasa.-" Dr. ScOtt's Commentary, has merted and obtained distinguish ed popularity. The spirit which pervades the work is excellent. is tho meek, aectionate, healing yet faithful spirit of the Gospel.

 Beside tke GbOve MANY OTHERS of the most iu- RuentiaL aOngt the Clergy hGUe recOHDeded tis 'OOr the JoiiOaUisg attracts hO'OeUer from Mr. EmerSons letter oM point out the adUGntages peculiar Co the OC- TAVO edition.

 Rep. Joseph Emerson, Author Of the EUGHgeIicM Primer" Six editions of this great work have bees published in this cOuntry.-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of all these editions, and decidedly of opinion, that most people would greatly prefer ARMSFRONG'S EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, the volumes not nearly so large as aae quarto editions but te paper finer and winter; the execution handsOmer; the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less inconvenience, it may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure. It has the advantage of be- ing cheaper less cumbersome, and more elegant.

 S'ARMSTRONG'S EDITION, therefore, is the one which most highly recommend for the use of families. It is peculiarly calculated supersede the of large Bible; and in two respects it will answer better purpose merely for reading the scrip tures as it is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same tine.''
